newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's Wallis report out on Wednesday - govt.
newsitem.headline: Australia's Wallis report out on Wednesday - govt.

text.p: The report from the official Wallis inquiry into the Australian financial system will be released at midday (0200 GMT) on Wednesday, Treasurer Peter Costello's office said on Tuesday.
The five-person Financial System Inquiry was set up in June last year and was chaired by prominent businessman Stan Wallis.
The Wallis Inquiry issued a preliminary discussion paper in November saying it would look at easing rules that stop mergers between the big four banks and the two major life groups.

This "six pillars" policy was developed by the former Labor government and applies to National Australia Bank Ltd, Westpac Banking Corp Ltd, ANZ Banking Group Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, National Mutual Holdings Ltd, and the Australian Mutual Provident Society (AMP).

It was widely expected that Wallis would recommend an easing of the "six pillars" policy, handing over judgement on such mergers to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) on competition grounds.

The Australian Financial Review reported earlier on Tuesday that the cabinet had rejected a Costello plan to substantially relax the merger rules, instead deciding to leave Costello with a discretionary veto over any big bank merger.

The Wallis Inquiry was also expected to make recommendations on reforming prudential regulation, reducing the number of regulators, and on foreign ownership, deposit insurance and access to payment systems.
